In Julia, Write a function `timezone_bumper(dt,bump)` that increases any provided timestamp by `bump::Int` hours (defaults to +3 hours). Make sure it works only for DateTime types and throws an error for Date types.

In Julia, you can use the built-in time library to work with dates and times. Here's a function that accomplishes what you're asking:

```julia
using Dates

function timezone_bumper(dt::DateTime; bump=3)
    return dt + Hour(bump)
end

function timezone_bumper(date::Date)
    error("Can only add hours to a DateTime type. A Date was provided instead.")
end
```
In this code, `DateTime` and `Hour` are types from the Dates library in Julia, which represents date and time values respectively. The function `timezone_bumper(dt::DateTime; bump=3)` takes a DateTime as input and increases it by the amount specified in `bump`. If no argument is provided for `bump`, it defaults to 3 hours.

The second function, `function timezone_bumper(date::Date)`, checks if you try to pass a Date type to this function and throws an error if so. This is because you can't add hours to a Date type - only DateTime can do that.
